  echo: true

## Getting Started

Install and launch R packages

The code chunk below uses p_load of pacman package to check if tidyverse package have been installed.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse, here)
```
:::



## Importing the Data

Importing polygon feature data in shapefile format



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/MasterPlan2014SubzoneBoundaryWebSHP", 
               layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\emmachew\ISSS626-emma-chew-en-chin\Hands-on Exercise\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial\MasterPlan2014SubzoneBoundaryWebSHP' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
```


:::
:::



Importing polyline feature data in shapefile format



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cyclingpath = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/CyclingPath_Apr2025", 
                         layer = "CyclingPathGazette")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `CyclingPathGazette' from data source 
  `C:\emmachew\ISSS626-emma-chew-en-chin\Hands-on Exercise\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial\CyclingPath_Apr2025' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 4651 features and 19 fields
Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 11721.1 ymin: 27550.13 xmax: 42809.37 ymax: 49702.59
Projected CRS: SVY21
```


:::
:::



Importing GIS data in kml format



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
preschool = st_read("data/geospatial/PreSchoolsLocation.kml")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `PRESCHOOLS_LOCATION' from data source 
  `C:\emmachew\ISSS626-emma-chew-en-chin\Hands-on Exercise\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial\PreSchoolsLocation.kml' 
  using driver `KML'

Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6878 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0

```


:::
:::



## Data Exploration

st_geometry() displays basic geospatial information.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_geometry(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Geometry set for 323 features 
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
First 5 geometries:
```


:::
:::



glimpse() shows the associated attribute information in the dataset.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(mpsz)
```

## Plotting Geospatial Data

Below is a multi-plot of all attributes.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Plotting only the geometry object.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(mpsz))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Plotting only the sf object.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz["PLN_AREA_N"])
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Plotting the preschool layer on top of the mpsz layer. However preschool point objects have failed to plot on top of mpsz layer. This happens because they have different coordinate systems.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(mpsz))
plot(st_geometry(preschool), 
     add = TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



## Projection Transformation

mpsz data frame is projected in SVY21, but EPSG code is wrong (should be 3414 instead of 9001).



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_crs(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: SVY21 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21[WGS84]",
        DATUM["World Geodetic System 1984",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
            ID["EPSG",6326]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]]],
    CONVERSION["unnamed",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],
        PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8802]],
        PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1,
            SCALEUNIT["unity",1],
            ID["EPSG",8805]],
        PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8806]],
        PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8807]]],
    CS[Cartesian,2],
        AXIS["(E)",east,
            ORDER[1],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1,
                ID["EPSG",9001]]],
        AXIS["(N)",north,
            ORDER[2],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1,
                ID["EPSG",9001]]]]
```


:::
:::



Assigning correct EPSG code to mpsz data frame.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz <- st_set_crs(mpsz, 3414)
st_crs(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: EPSG:3414 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21 / Singapore TM",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21",
        DATUM["SVY21",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
        ID["EPSG",4757]],
    CONVERSION["Singapore Transverse Mercator",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],
        PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8802]],
        PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1,
            SCALEUNIT["unity",1],
            ID["EPSG",8805]],
        PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8806]],
        PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8807]]],
    CS[Cartesian,2],
        AXIS["northing (N)",north,
            ORDER[1],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
        AXIS["easting (E)",east,
            ORDER[2],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],

        AREA["Singapore - onshore and offshore."],

    ID["EPSG",3414]]
```


:::
:::



Transformation of projection of preschool data from WGS84 to SVY21



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
preschool <- st_transform(preschool, 
                              crs = 3414)
st_crs(preschool)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

::: {.cell}

```

## Importing and Converting Aspatial Data



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
listings <- read_csv("data/aspatial/listings.csv")
```

## Creating a simple feature data frame from an aspatial data frame

In coords argument, column name of x-coordinates is listed first, then followed by column name of y-coordinates. In crs argument, it requires the coordinates system in epsg format.(EPSG: 4326 is wgs84 Geographic Coordinate System and EPSG: 3414 is Singapore SVY21 Projected Coordinate System.)



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
listings_sf <- st_as_sf(listings, 
                       coords = c("longitude", "latitude"),
                       crs=4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)
glimpse(listings_sf)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

## Geoprocessing with sf packages

sf package can perform geoprocessing functions (i.e. GIS analysis).

### Use case 1: Land acquisition analysis

Task: to determine the extent of land needed to be acuired in the total area, to upgrade an existing cycling path.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling <- st_buffer(
  cyclingpath, dist=5, nQuadSegs = 30)
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling$AREA <- st_area(buffer_cycling)
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling <- buffer_cycling %>%
  mutate(AREA = st_area(geometry))
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sum(buffer_cycling$AREA)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
3561648 [m^2]
```


:::
:::



Create a plot showing the buffer within a selected planning subzone (e.g. Tampines West). First, project the buffer_cycling data to EPSG:3414 format.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling <- st_set_crs(buffer_cycling, 3414)
st_crs(buffer_cycling)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: EPSG:3414 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21 / Singapore TM",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21",
        DATUM["SVY21",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
        ID["EPSG",4757]],
    CONVERSION["Singapore Transverse Mercator",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],

            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,

            ID["EPSG",8802]],

```


:::
:::



Next, filter to "Tampines West" and plot the intersection.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz_selected <- mpsz %>%
  filter(SUBZONE_N == "TAMPINES WEST") 
buffer_cycling_selected <- st_intersection(
  buffer_cycling, mpsz_selected)
plot(st_geometry(buffer_cycling_selected))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Use case 2: Determine the number of pre-schools by planning subzone

Use R and sf package to perform necessary geoprocessing to compute these counts.

First, identify pre-schools located inside each Planning Subzone by using st_intersects(). Next, length() of Base R is used to calculate numbers of pre-schools that fall inside each planning subzone.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz$`PreSch Count`<- lengths(st_intersects(mpsz, preschool))
```
:::



This is the summary statistics for PreSchCount.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(mpsz$`PreSch Count`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   0.00    0.00    4.00    7.09   10.00   72.00 
```


:::
:::



This lists the planning subzone with the most number of pre-schools.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
top_n(mpsz, 1, `PreSch Count`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 16 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 39655.33 ymin: 35966 xmax: 42940.57 ymax: 38622.37
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM
  OBJECTID SUBZONE_NO     SUBZONE_N SUBZONE_C CA_IND PLN_AREA_N PLN_AREA_C
1      189          2 TAMPINES EAST    TMSZ02      N   TAMPINES         TM
     REGION_N REGION_C          INC_CRC FMEL_UPD_D   X_ADDR   Y_ADDR SHAPE_Leng
1 EAST REGION       ER 21658EAAF84F4D8D 2014-12-05 41122.55 37392.39   10180.62
  SHAPE_Area                       geometry PreSch Count
1    4339824 MULTIPOLYGON (((42196.76 38...           72
```


:::
:::



st_area() is used to derive the area of each planning subzone. mutate() is then used to compute the density.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz$Area <- mpsz %>%
  st_area()

mpsz <- mpsz %>%
  mutate(`PreSch Density` = `PreSch Count`/Area * 1000000)
```
:::



Using hist(), we can plot a histogram to show the distribution of PreSch Density.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mpsz$`PreSch Density`)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Using ggplot2, we can customise the histogram.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=mpsz, 
       aes(x= as.numeric(`PreSch Density`)))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="black", 
                 fill="light blue") +
  labs(title = "Are pre-school evenly distributed in Singapore?",
       subtitle= "There are many planning subzones with a single pre-school, on the other hand, \nthere are seven planning subzones with at least 30 or more pre-schools",
      x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
      y = "Frequency")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



A scatterplot showing the relationship between Pre-school Density and Pre-school Count can be created using ggplot.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=mpsz, 
       aes(y = `PreSch Count`, 
           x= as.numeric(`PreSch Density`)))+
  geom_point(color="black", 
             fill="light blue") +
  xlim(0, 40) +
  ylim(0, 40) +
  labs(title = "",
      x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
      y = "Pre-school count")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
